Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Dynamically Tunable Low-Loss Active Metamaterials For Wireless Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective
The overall goal of this project is to develop fast (~nanosecond) tunable-over-a-wide-band, low-loss, physically small, metamaterial-based RF front-end elements compatible with Digital-RF transceiver concept being developed in industry for a variety of commercial and military applications. We will focus on novel metamaterials based on superconductor elements to form extremely low insertion loss, physically and electrically small, highly tunable structures for the next generation of RF electronics. These metamaterials will allow us to increase performance while decreasing size and signature of antennas operating over wide bands, multibands and allowing dynamic real-time tuning.
Intellectual Merit
The work will include the Josephson effect into metamaterials for the first time, leading to development of radical new applications of metamaterials and test several high-risk theoretical predictions.
Broader Impacts
The proposed work investigates and promotes applications of metamaterials for the RF and microwave industry. These developments will be of direct and measurable value to society through the generation of high-tech jobs, improvement of wireless communications, and a positive impact on quality of life. The PI has a history of broadening the participation of underrepresented groups (currently 50% of the research group are members of underrepresented groups), and is involved in numerous outreach activities. These activities will create new partnerships, collaborations, and facilities that will alter the landscape of the superconducting metamaterials field. The results will be disseminated through publications, talks and posters at international conferences, a research web site, and continuation of the extensive outreach activities by the PI and students.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many fantasy novels, including the Harry Potter series, imagine a magical cloak that causes objects to disappear from view.  Metamaterials research has taken cloaking from the realm of magic to reality. However, most present cloaking devices only work at a single frequency. It means that Harry Potter is only invisible, for example, in green light - Oops… Can we create a cloak that is undetectable over a broader spectrum, and even better, is tailorable and tunable? Here we present a novel macroscopic quantum metamaterial exhibiting self-induced, tunable, and switchable transparency behavior over a wide frequency range.

The metamaterial is built from a large collection of identical meta-atoms called radio frequency Superconducting QUantum Interference Devices (rf-SQUIDs).  Both a single meta-atom and the full metamaterial show a nearly complete disappearance of resonance absorption with manipulation of numerous parameters, including temperature, the drive amplitude, tiny amounts of dc magnetic field, and both magnetic and driving frequency history. The unique tunable, hysteretic, and broadband transparency behavior results from the intrinsic bi-stability of the rf-SQUID, which is extremely nonlinear and very sensitive to magnetic field because it combines two macroscopic quantum effects: magnetic flux quantization and the Josephson effect.  Experiment, numerical simulation, and analytical solutions of the governing equations are all in detailed agreement. The phenomenon can be understood in quantitative detail using the tools of nonlinear dynamics.

This work serves to link the fields of quantitative nonlinear dynamics and macroscopic quantum effects to the metamaterials community.  It also introduces revolutionary new applications of metamaterials, enabling fast tunable digital filters, self-induced power limiting, digital communication transmitters, gain modulated quantum antennas, and the novel concept of a metamaterial that automatically reduces its scattering cross section to near zero (auto-cloaking). 

 


Last Modified: 10/30/2015
Modified by: Steven M Anlage

Image
  • (a) Experimental setup for measuring transparency of SQUID metamaterial. Transmission of a single meta-atom at 4.6 K depending on frequency and rf flux shown in (b) experiment and (c) simulation. Insets plot the transparency vs. input power for (b) experiment and (c) simulation.
    Daimeng Zhang, University of Maryland
    Copyrighted
    Steven M Anlage
    Transparency in RF SQUID metamaterials
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Many fantasy novels, including the Harry Potter series, imagine a magical cloak that causes objects to disappear from view. Metamaterials research has taken cloaking from the realm of magic to reality. However, most present cloaking devices only work at a single frequency. It means that Harry Potter is only invisible, for example, in green light - Oops… Can we create a cloak that is undetectable over a broader spectrum, and even better, is tailorable and tunable? Here we present a novel macroscopic quantum metamaterial exhibiting self-induced, tunable, and switchable transparency behavior over a wide frequency range. The metamaterial is built from a large collection of identical meta-atoms called radio frequency Superconducting QUantum Interference Devices (rf-SQUIDs). Both a single meta-atom and the full metamaterial show a nearly complete disappearance of resonance absorption with manipulation of numerous parameters, including temperature, the drive amplitude, tiny amounts of dc magnetic field, and both magnetic and driving frequency history. The unique tunable, hysteretic, and broadband transparency behavior results from the intrinsic bi-stability of the rf-SQUID, which is extremely nonlinear and very sensitive to magnetic field because it combines two macroscopic quantum effects: magnetic flux quantization and the Josephson effect. Experiment, numerical simulation, and analytical solutions of the governing equations are all in detailed agreement. It also introduces revolutionary new applications of metamaterials, enabling fast tunable digital filters, self-induced power limiting, digital communication transmitters, gain modulated quantum antennas, and the novel concept of a metamaterial that automatically reduces its scattering cross section to near zero (auto-cloaking).
